t: Proverbs 27
Do*pn not boast about tomorrow, for*ld you do not know what a day may bring.
Let*ln another praise you, and not your own mouth; a*ld stranger, and not your own lips.
A*ln stone is heavy, and sand is weighty, but*ld a fool’s provocation is heavier than both.
Wrath*ln is cruel, anger is overwhelming, but*ld who can stand before jealousy?
Better*ln is open rebuke than*ld hidden love.
Faithful*ln are the wounds of a friend; profuse*ld are the kisses of an enemy.
One*ln who is full loathes honey, but*ld to one who is hungry everything bitter is sweet.
Like*ln a bird that strays from its nest is*ld a man who strays from his home.
Oil*ln and perfume make the heart glad, and*ld the sweetness of a friend comes from his earnest counsel.
Do*ln not forsake your friend and your father’s friend, and*ld do not go to your brother’s house in the day of your calamity. Better*ln is a neighbor who is near than*ld a brother who is far away.
Be*ln wise, my son, and make my heart glad, that*ld I may answer him who reproaches me.
The*ln prudent sees danger and hides himself, but*ld the simple go on and suffer for it.
Take*ln a man’s garment when he has put up security for a stranger, and*ld hold it in pledge when he puts up security for an adulteress.
Whoever*ln blesses his neighbor with a loud voice, rising*ld early in the morning, will*ld be counted as cursing.
A*ln continual dripping on a rainy day and*ld a quarrelsome wife are alike;
to*ln restrain her is to restrain the wind or*ld to grasp oil in one’s right hand.
Iron*ln sharpens iron, and*ld one man sharpens another.
Whoever*ln tends a fig tree will eat its fruit, and*ld he who guards his master will be honored.
As*ln in water face reflects face, so*ld the heart of man reflects the man.
Sheol*ln and Abaddon are never satisfied, and*ld never satisfied are the eyes of man.
The*ln crucible is for silver, and the furnace is for gold, and*ld a man is tested by his praise.
Crush*ln a fool in a mortar with a pestle along*ld with crushed grain, yet*ld his folly will not depart from him.
Know*pn well the condition of your flocks, and*ld give attention to your herds,
for*ln riches do not last forever; and*ld does a crown endure to all generations?
When*ln the grass is gone and the new growth appears and*ld the vegetation of the mountains is gathered,
the*ln lambs will provide your clothing, and*ld the goats the price of a field.
There*ln will be enough goats’ milk for your food, for*ld the food of your household and*ld maintenance for your girls.
